importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Diwali is celebrated on this date, marking the start of the festival's main observance, and serves as a global cultural event for over a billion people of South Asian origin.
Sikhs commemorate Bandi Chhor Divas on this date, marking the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 Hindu kings from imprisonment, a key historical and religious event in Sikh tradition.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Diwali occurs annually in autumn, typically between October and November, aligning with seasonal transitions and cultural rhythms in South Asia and diaspora communities.

keyTakeAways: Diwali, also known as Deepavali, is a major festival celebrated by over a billion Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists worldwide.

It symbolizes the triumph of light over darkness, good over evil, and is rooted in various religious and mythological stories such as Rama and Sita’s return, Krishna’s victory over Narakasura, and the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings.
The festival lasts five days, with key days including Dhanteras, Choti Diwali, Diwali (Lakshmi Puja), Padwa/Govardhan Puja, and Bhai Dooj, each with specific traditions and rituals.
Despite religious roots, Diwali is now widely celebrated by people of all faiths and backgrounds, functioning as a cultural and community-based celebration of unity, family, and renewal.

Celebrations include lighting oil lamps (diyas), decorating homes with rangolis, feasting on sweets, exchanging gifts, and opening new business accounts, reflecting both spiritual and economic significance.
In Sikh tradition, Bandi Chhor Divas on October 21, 2025, marks the release of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings from imprisonment, highlighting themes of justice and freedom.

namedEntities.name: Hindus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major religious group that celebrates Diwali, with traditions including worship of Lakshmi and stories from the Ramayana.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hindus are central to Diwali’s religious narratives, such as the story of Rama and Sita’s return from exile, which forms a key part of the festival's spiritual meaning.

namedEntities.name: Sikhs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A religious community that observes Diwali as Bandi Chhor Divas, commemorating the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Sikhs mark Diwali as a day of liberation, emphasizing justice, freedom, and resistance to oppression, adding a unique historical and spiritual dimension to the festival.

namedEntities.name: Jains
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A religious group that celebrates Diwali as the day Lord Mahavira attained enlightenment and passed into physical death.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Jains interpret Diwali as a day of spiritual enlightenment, contributing to the festival’s diverse religious meanings and interfaith significance.

namedEntities.name: Buddhists
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A religious group that observes Diwali as the day Emperor Ashoka embraced Buddhism.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Buddhists associate Diwali with the conversion of Emperor Ashoka, adding a historical and philosophical layer to the festival’s cultural resonance.

namedEntities.name: Rama
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Hindu deity, an incarnation of Vishnu, whose return from exile is central to one Diwali legend.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rama’s story is a key narrative in the festival’s meaning, symbolizing the triumph of good over evil and the return of justice.

namedEntities.name: Sita
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Hindu goddess and wife of Rama, symbolizing devotion and resilience, central to the Rama story.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Sita’s kidnapping and rescue by Rama are central to the Rama legend, reinforcing Diwali’s themes of sacrifice and triumph.

namedEntities.name: Ravana
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A demon king in Hindu mythology, defeated by Rama, symbolizing evil and oppression.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ravana’s defeat is a core narrative in Diwali, representing the triumph of good over evil and justice.

namedEntities.name: Krishna
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Hindu deity who defeats the demon king Narakasura, marking a key Diwali legend.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Krishna’s victory over Narakasura is a foundational story for Diwali celebrations in western and southern India.

namedEntities.name: Narakasura
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A demon king defeated by Lord Krishna, whose imprisonment symbolizes the triumph of good over evil.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The story of Narakasura’s defeat is central to the Diwali narrative in parts of India, emphasizing liberation and justice.

namedEntities.name: Lakshmi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Hindu goddess of wealth, prosperity, and fortune, worshipped during Diwali.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lakshmi is central to the worship and rituals during Diwali, especially on the main day when families pray for prosperity.

namedEntities.name: Dhanvantari
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Hindu god of Ayurveda and healing, honored on Dhanteras.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dhanvantari is honored on Dhanteras, a day when people purchase new household items and clean their homes for good fortune.

namedEntities.name: Yamaraj
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Hindu god of death, honored on Dhanteras.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Yamaraj is one of the deities honored on Dhanteras, reflecting the day’s spiritual focus on balance between life and death.

namedEntities.name: Govardhan Hill
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A hill in Vrindavan, lifted by Lord Krishna to protect villagers from rains, commemorated on Padwa.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The event of Krishna lifting Govardhan Hill is central to the Padwa tradition, symbolizing divine protection and human devotion.

namedEntities.name: Guru Hargobind
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The sixth Sikh guru, whose liberation from imprisonment is celebrated as Bandi Chhor Divas.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Guru Hargobind’s release from captivity is a key historical and religious event in Sikh Diwali observance.

namedEntities.name: Emperor Ashoka
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Mauryan emperor who embraced Buddhism, acknowledged by some Buddhists as a key figure in Diwali.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ashoka’s conversion to Buddhism is cited as a significant moment in Diwali’s Buddhist interpretation, adding interfaith depth.

namedEntities.name: Lord Mahavira
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The last Jain spiritual leader, who attained enlightenment and physical death on Diwali.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Mahavira’s enlightenment is central to Jain Diwali, marking a spiritual milestone and a key religious tradition.

namedEntities.name: Dhanteras
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The first day of Diwali, marked by buying gold, silver, and cleaning homes.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dhanteras is a key day in the Diwali sequence, emphasizing renewal, wealth, and spiritual preparation.

namedEntities.name: Choti Diwali
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The second day of Diwali, marking Lord Krishna’s victory over Narakasura.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This day celebrates Krishna’s triumph, highlighting themes of justice and liberation.

namedEntities.name: Diwali (Lakshmi Puja)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The third day of Diwali, when families gather for feasting, gift exchange, and Lakshmi worship.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This day is the main celebration of Diwali, representing family, prosperity, and cultural unity.

namedEntities.name: Padwa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The fourth day of Diwali, honoring husband-wife relationships and Krishna’s protection of villagers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Padwa reflects social values like marital harmony and divine protection, adding a familial and community layer.

namedEntities.name: Bhai Dooj
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The final day of Diwali, celebrating sibling love and bonds.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bhai Dooj underscores familial bonds, a key aspect of Diwali’s social and emotional significance.

namedEntities.name: Deepavali
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An alternative name for Diwali, derived from Sanskrit meaning 'row of lights'.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The name Deepavali emphasizes the festival’s core symbolism of light and illumination.

namedEntities.name: 52 Hindu kings

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This number emphasizes the scale of liberation, showing Diwali as a narrative of rescue and justice.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Traditional Diwali celebrations involving oil lamps and firecrackers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These are key visual and cultural elements that mark Diwali celebrations globally and symbolize light and joy.

namedEntities.name: Sweets

summaryOfNewsArticle: Diwali, a major festival celebrated by over a billion Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists worldwide, marks the triumph of light over darkness and good over evil. Observed annually in autumn between October and November, it spans five days, each with distinct traditions such as Dhanteras (purchase of new items), Choti Diwali (Krishna's victory over Narakasura), Diwali (Lakshmi Puja), Padwa (husband-wife harmony), and Bhai Dooj (sibling bonds). The festival has deep religious roots, including stories from the Ramayana, Krishna’s legend, and the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings by Sikhs, as well as the enlightenment of Lord Mahavira for Jains. While rooted in spirituality, Diwali is now widely celebrated as a cultural and community event, featuring light decorations, feasting, and family gatherings. It also marks the start of the new Hindu financial year and is observed globally in South Asia and beyond, symbolizing renewal, prosperity, and unity across diverse faiths and cultures.
title: It’s Diwali, a time for light, community and fresh starts
